marketNews.title: BI Holds Interest Rate, As Expected
marketNews.content: Bank Indonesia decided to keep the BI Rate at 5.75% on Wednesday (19/2). The deposit facility and lending facility were also maintained at 5% and 6.5% respectively. The decision aligns with consensus expectations. Governor Perry Warjiyo said the move aims to stabilise the rupiah exchange rate, keep inflation under control, and support economic growth. He noted there is still room for a further BI Rate cut, mainly because inflation is low and to support growth, but the timing of the next cut will depend on global dynamics. Bloomberg consensus expects the BI Rate to fall another 50 basis points to 5.25% by the end of 2025. Bank Indonesia also kept its expectation of a 25 basis point Fed rate cut in 2025, the same as last month, consistent with consensus based on the CME FedWatch Tool as of Wednesday (19/2). Perry emphasized maintaining rupiah stability through pro‑market monetary instruments such as SRBI, SVBI and SUVBI. In addition, the revision of foreign exchange rules for export proceeds of natural resources effective 1 March 2025 is expected to support rupiah stability. The central bank also raised the macro‑prudential liquidity incentive (KLM) ceiling from a maximum of 4% of DPK to a maximum of 5% of DPK. The KLM incentive for the housing sector, including low‑income housing, will be increased gradually from 23 trillion rupiah to about 80 trillion rupiah as of 1 April 2025 to support the government’s housing programme. On Wednesday (19/2), the Jakarta Composite Index (IHSG) fell 1.14%, the rupiah weakened 0.42% to 16,339 per US dollar, and the 10‑year government bond yield rose 14 basis points to 6.901%.

marketNews.title: Key Takeaway
marketNews.content: The decision was received negatively by the market, with the Jakarta Composite Index recording a net foreign outflow in the regular market of 964 billion rupiah today, halting the foreign inflow trend of the previous two days. Interest‑rate‑sensitive sectors such as banking/finance (-1.78%) and property (-0.80%) declined today. On the other hand, the increase in KLM incentives could be a fresh boost for the banking sector, given the generally tight liquidity conditions.

marketNews.title: Bank Indonesia Records Slowing Credit Growth
marketNews.content: Bank Indonesia reported that bank credit growth slowed to 10.27% year‑on‑year in the first month of 2025 (1M25), down from 10.39% YoY in 2024, marking the lowest growth since November 2023 and below the central bank’s target range of 11‑13%. Investment credit grew 13.22% YoY, consumer credit 10.37% YoY, and working‑capital credit 8.4% YoY. Sharia financing grew 9.71% YoY and MSME credit grew 2.88% YoY. Going forward, Bank Indonesia will continue to promote credit growth through accommodative macro‑prudential policies to support the economy.

marketNews.title: Coal Price Decline Affects Domestic Production
marketNews.content: The Acting Executive Director of the Indonesian Coal Mining Association, Gita Mahyarani, said on Tuesday (18/2) that the recent decline in coal prices will lead to a balance in domestic coal production, as current production costs remain high. Coal prices touched $102 per ton on Tuesday (18/2), near a four‑year low. Prolonged price declines will first affect miners in regions with high logistics costs such as Central Kalimantan and Jambi. The price drop is closely linked to increased production this year, targeting the two largest importers, China and India.

marketNews.title: President Prabowo Appoints New Minister of Higher Education, Science and Technology
marketNews.content: President Prabowo Subianto on Wednesday (19/2) appointed Brian Yuliarto as the new Minister of Higher Education, Science and Technology, replacing Satryo Brodjonegoro. This marks the first cabinet reshuffle since Prabowo took office in October 2024 and may indicate how he handles controversies among his ministers. The reshuffle follows a January 2025 demonstration by ministry staff over Satryo’s leadership style. Brian Yuliarto currently serves as Vice Rector for Research and Innovation at the Bandung Institute of Technology.

marketNews.title: Deputy Finance Minister on Budget Efficiency
marketNews.content: Deputy Finance Minister Suahasil Nazara said on Tuesday (18/2) that the total budget savings the government achieved through efficiency remained unchanged at 306.7 trillion rupiah. His statement came after President Prabowo claimed that the first‑year budget savings reached 750 trillion rupiah, comprising reductions in the state treasury budget, ministry/agency efficiencies, and BUMN dividend receipts. Suahasil declined further comment on the higher savings figure cited by the president, while the presidential spokesperson has not commented. Despite the savings, the Ministry of Finance projected the 2025 fiscal deficit to stay at 2.53%.

marketNews.title: Presidential Adviser on Free Lunch Program Budget Increase
marketNews.content: Presidential adviser and brother of President Prabowo, Hashim Djojohadikusumo, said on Wednesday (19/2) that the government increased the budget for the free lunch program in 2025 from 71 trillion rupiah to 171 trillion rupiah. He claimed that, according to the National Development Planning Agency, the new budget would contribute +2 percentage points to Indonesia’s economic growth, higher than the initial +0.83 percentage points. He also claimed the program would reach 82 million people, up from the initial estimate of 17.5 million. Previously, the Finance Ministry said the new budget would reach about 40 million people in 2025, while the Head of the National Nutrition Agency said it would reach nearly 83 million people.

tickerNews.title: TPIA Rumored IPO Before Mid‑2025
tickerNews.content: Katadata reported that Chandra Asri Pacific will bring its infrastructure subsidiary, PT Chandra Daya Investasi, to an IPO on the IDX before mid‑2025. TPIA has not responded to the issue. Previously, TPIA disclosed in an information note in August 2024 that the company was exploring the possibility of an IPO for PT Chandra Daya Investasi, but the plan remained in internal discussion.

tickerNews.title: ARNA Reports 4Q24 Net Profit of 110 Billion Rupiah
tickerNews.content: Arwana Citramulia reported a net profit of 110 billion rupiah in 4Q24 (‑2% QoQ, +19% YoY). The 2024 net profit totaled 424 billion rupiah (‑4% YoY), matching expectations at 100.5% of Stockbit’s estimate. The result aligns with the turnaround thesis in the Unboxing ARNA report, where the company posted a 17% YoY revenue increase in 4Q24, indicating consistent revenue recovery over recent quarters (2Q24: +4% YoY, 3Q24: +14% YoY). Revenue growth was supported by a 11.7% YoY increase in sales volume in 4Q24, leading to a 7.4% YoY rise in total 2024 sales volume. Gross margin fell slightly to 34.3% (‑20 bps QoQ, ‑60 bps YoY), but EBIT margin rose to 20.1% (+0 bps QoQ, +30 bps YoY).

tickerNews.title: ISAT Director Purchases Approximately 1.2 Million Shares
tickerNews.content: Indosat CEO Vikram Sinha bought about 1.2 million ISAT shares at an average price of 1,721 rupiah per share on 13 February 2025. The total transaction value was roughly 2 billion rupiah. After the purchase, Vikram’s ownership in ISAT increased from 0.0093% to 0.0129%.

tickerNews.title: AMMN Requests Export Concentrate Relief Amid Slow Smelter Commissioning
tickerNews.content: Amman Mineral International, through its subsidiary PT Amman Mineral Nusa Tenggara (AMNT), asked the government to relax export restrictions on copper concentrate as the commissioning of its smelter proceeds slower than planned. AMNT’s CEO Rachmat Makkasau said the smelter, valued at 21 trillion rupiah, is operating at about 48% capacity since commissioning began in June 2024, due to extensive efforts to avoid issues with the new technology. The company continues to accelerate commissioning, including adding workforce beyond the original plan.

tickerNews.title: GOTO Engages Ministry Over Online Driver THR
tickerNews.content: Ade Mulya, Chief of Public Policy & Government Relations at GoTo (Gojek Tokopedia), said the company is intensively coordinating with the Ministry of Manpower regarding the holiday allowance (THR) for online motorcycle taxi drivers. He explained that GoTo is committed to helping within its capacity. Earlier this week, online driver demonstrations demanded THR equal to the provincial minimum wage (UMP). Labor Minister Yassierli said the government will finalize THR rules for online drivers soon, without specifying the amount. Deputy Labor Minister Immanuel Ebenezer urged ride‑hailing platform operators to provide THR in cash rather than rice, sugar, or other staples.

tickerNews.title: TLKM Signals Potential Share Buyback
tickerNews.content: Telkom Indonesia CEO Ririek Adriansyah signaled that the company will conduct a share buyback, though he did not provide further details. He only stated that the buyback plan will be announced at the appropriate time.

tickerNews.title: PGEO Signs Cooperation Agreement with Sinopec Star
tickerNews.content: Pertamina Geothermal Energy signed a cooperation agreement with Sinopec Star Co. Ltd., a subsidiary of China Petrochemical Corporation, to develop geothermal energy and explore green hydrogen opportunities in Indonesia, China, and other potential global markets.

tickerNews.title: WIKA Reports No New Contracts Until 14 February 2025
tickerNews.content: Wijaya Karya Company Secretary Mahendra Vijaya said the company has not recorded any new contracts up to 14 February 2025, leading WIKA to postpone repayment of bonds and sukuk maturing on 18 February 2025. He explained that WIKA faces challenging business conditions due to a decline in project tenders in 2024 from government, state‑owned enterprises, and private sectors. WIKA plans to broaden its market focus to capture projects from government, SOEs, and private players, and to seek strategic cooperation with domestic and foreign partners to increase future project acquisition. Previously, the IDX temporarily halted WIKA trading on Tuesday (18/2) pending payment of principal on bonds and sukuk due on 18 February 2025.

tickerNews.title: PRDA Plans IPO of Diagnostic Line Within 2‑3 Years
tickerNews.content: Prodia Widyahusada Chairman Andi Wijaya said the company plans to bring its subsidiary PT Prodia Diagnostic Line (Proline) to an IPO within the next 2‑3 years. PRDA currently holds 39% of Proline, while its controlling shareholder PT Prodia Utama is the main shareholder of Proline. Established in 2010, Proline produces clinical chemistry reagents, urine strips, molecular products, immunology reagents, rapid diagnostic test instruments, in‑vitro diagnostic (IVD) instruments, and spare parts. Proline supplies products to 4,800 of Indonesia’s 10,416 health centers and is building a new facility in Jababeka, Cikarang, targeted to start operations in April 2025. Production capacity will triple, with hematology reagents reaching 180,000 packs per year and clinical chemistry kits reaching 960,000 kits per year.

tickerNews.title: Kalbe Farma Shareholder Approves Treasury Stock Cancellation
tickerNews.content: Kalbe Farma shareholders, in a rights issue (RUPSLB) on Monday (17/2), approved the cancellation of 61.7 million treasury shares, representing 0.13% of total outstanding shares. After the corporate action, the number of KLBF shares listed on the IDX became 46.8 billion.

tickerNews.title: MDIY Issues Options for MESOP Phase 1
tickerNews.content: Daya Intiguna Yasa announced the issuance of 127.1 million option rights for the MESOP Phase 1 program on 18 February 2025. The exercise price is 1,650 rupiah per share, and the options are valid until 6 August 2029.

tickerNews.title: CYBR Chairman Purchases 3.2 Million Shares
tickerNews.content: ITSEC Asia Chairman Patrick Rudolf Dannacher bought 3.2 million CYBR shares at an average price of 554 rupiah per share on 17 February 2025. The total transaction value was about 1.8 billion rupiah. After the purchase, his ownership in CYBR increased from 0.296% to 0.321%.
